title: Machine Learning Meets a Particle Accelerator
authors: Chris Tennant, Adam Carpenter, Tom Powers, Anna Solopova, Lasitha Vidyaratne, Khan Iftekharuddin
abstract: Particle accelerators are arguably the most complex scientific instruments ever built. Working as an accelerator physicist at a user-facility, the goal is to maximize scientific output per operating dollar. Given the enormous amount of data generated by accelerators and the increasing demands on system performance, we recognize the need to leverage machine learning (ML). This talk reports on a time-series classification project where I've been involved in the full life-cycle of the project - from data exploration through deployment. During the project we have utilized supervised learning (both conventional and deep methods) as well as unsupervised learning.

title: Balancing Rational and Other-Regarding Preferences in Cooperative-Competitive Environments
authors: Dmitry Ivanov, Vladimir Egorov, Alexey Shpilman
abstract: Recent studies extensively explore the interplay between cooperative and competitive behaviour in mixed environments, where purely rational agents often struggle to achieve stable cooperation. A prevalent approach to induce cooperative behaviour is to assign additional rewards based on other agents' well-being. However, this approach suffers from the issues of multi-agent credit assignment and non-stationarity. These issues are efficiently alleviated in cooperative setting with such algorithms as QMIX and COMA. As an extension of these algorithms for mixed environments, we propose BAROCCO. Our algorithm is compatible with both Q-learning and Actor-Critic frameworks and is capable to balance individual and social incentives.

title: Interpreting word embeddings using a distribution agnostic approach employing Hellinger distance
authors: Tamás Ficsor, Gábor Berend
abstract: Word embeddings can encode semantic and syntactic features and have achieved many recent successes in solving NLP tasks. Despite their successes, it is not trivial to directly extract lexical information out of them. In this paper, we propose a transformation of the embedding space to a more interpretable one using the Hellinger distance. We additionally suggest a distribution-agnostic approach using Kernel Density Estimation. Furthermore method is introduced to measure the interpretability of the word embeddings in a dimension independent manner.

title: Order Altering Language Constructions Promote Generalization to Unseen Instructions of Ordinary Order​
authors: Vladislav Kurenkov, Bulat Maksudov, Adil Khan
abstract: We analyze the performance of general deep reinforcement learning algorithms on a task-oriented language grounding problem, where language input contains multiple tasks and the model has no prior linguistic knowledge. In this preliminary work, we particularly focus on the language input with constructions that alter the order of execution. Our results  show  that  the  introduction  of  such  constructions  in  the training language input consistently improves the generalization to a higher number of tasks up from 3% to 14% over the different variations of training algorithms.

title: Continual Lerning with Gated Incremental Memories fro sequential data processing
authors: Andrea Cossu, Antonio Carta, Davide Bacciu
abstract: The ability to learn in dynamic, nonstationary environments without forgetting previous knowledge, also known as Continual Learning (CL), is a key enabler for scalable and trustworthy deployments of adaptive solutions. This work proposes a Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) architecture for CL that is able to deal with drift in input distribution without forgetting previously acquired knowledge. We compare the performances of our enhanced architecture against EWC and RNNs on a set of standard CL benchmarks. Results show the superior performance of our architecture and highlight the need for special solutions designed to address CL in RNNs.

title: A Robust FD&I Methodology for Solenoid Pumps based on Discriminative Features
authors: Akpudo Ugochukwu Ejike and Jang-Wook Hur
abstract: The need for accurate condition monitoring of hydraulic components (solenoid pumps) has attracted extensive research studies on techniques for optimized fault detection and isolation (FD&I). Because Mechanical vibrational signals reflect operational conditions, effective and efficient FD&I techniques depend largely on the discriminative nature of extracted features for diagnosis. Our study focusses on a multi-domain feature extraction procedure, discriminative feature selection using the binary particle swarm optimization (BPSO) algorithm, and fault isolation by the Gaussian kernel support vector machine (SVM*). The performance was tested on five VSC63A5 solenoid pumps at various operating (fault) conditions with a test accuracy of 99.6%.

title: BERT for Evidence Retrieval andClaim Verification
authors: Amir Soleimani
abstract: I explain how we use the BERT model for claim verification and evidence sentence retrieval. I explain both pointwise and pairwise approaches for the retrieval model and address the problem of trivial negative samples. Finally, I present how hard negative mining can improve performance.

title: BERT for Romanian Language Understanding
authors: Stefan Daniel Dumitrescu, Andrei-Marius Avram, Sampo Pyysalo
abstract: We introduce Romanian BERT, the first purely Romanian transformer-based language model, pretrained on 15.2 GB of text. To validate the model, we evaluated it on various Romanian datasets and compared its results with the ones obtained by Multilingual BERT; it outperformed Multilingual BERT on all tasks. We open sourced the pretrained model, the evaluation code, and some practical examples of fine-tuning at: https://github.com/dumitrescustefan/Romanian-Transformes.

title: Breakdown Detection in Negotiation Dialogues
authors: Atsuki Yamaguchi, Katsuhide Fujita
abstract: In human-human negotiation, reaching a rational agreement can be difficult, and unfortunately, the negotiations sometimes break down because of conflicts of interests. If artificial intelligence can play a role in assisting with human-human negotiation, it can assist in avoiding negotiation breakdown, leading to a rational agreement. Therefore, this study focuses on end-to-end tasks for predicting the outcome of a negotiation dialogue in natural language.

title: A study of natural alpha embeddings on a decomposable attention model
authors: Uddhipan Thakur, Riccardo Volpi, Luigi Malago
abstract: Natural alpha embeddings are geometrically deformed embeddings obtained from deforming the manifold created by conditional models. We test such emdeddings for a NLI task by implementing a decomposable attention model introduced by Parikh et al, on the SNLI dataset. Several parameter values of alpha are implemented and the results for each are compared against those of the standard Glove embeddings usually used in such contexts.

title: Eikonal solution using physics-informed neural networks
authors: Umair bin Waheed1, Ehsan Haghighat2, Tariq Alkhalifah3, Chao Song3, Qi Hao1
abstract: Deep learning is fast emerging as a potential disruptive tool to tackle longstanding research problems across the sciences. Recent advances in the field of Scientific Machine Learning demonstrate its largely untapped potential in scientific computing. Here, we employ the emerging paradigm of physics-informed neural networks to solve the P-wave eikonal equation. By minimizing a loss function formed by imposing the eikonal equation, we train a neural network to produce travel-time solutions that are consistent with the underlying equation. This approach is particularly attractive as it can speed up seismic imaging and inversion applications significantly.

title: Comments on Y.Bengio et al. (2019)
authors: Roberto-Rafael Maura-Rivero
abstract: The authors of Y.Bengio et al. (2019) provided a new method to disentangle the causal mechanism between 2 variables A and B by exploiting the fact that, if you observe A and B before and after an intervention on A, it is faster to update the distribution of your variables if you assumed the correct causal structure. On top of the paper, I will comment on the limitations of the method in real life scenarios if we go slightly away of their assumptions.

title: AirCalypse: Revealing Fine-Grained Air Quality from Social Media
authors: Prithviraj Pramanik, Subrata Nandi, Mousumi Saha
abstract: Air Pollution has been a growing menace in developing countries. An effective ambient air monitoring system needs to be present that can provide a city-wide fine-grained air quality map for effective policymaking. The existing ambient air quality monitoring stations incur high installation & maintenance costs and suffer from sparse coverage. On the other hand, in recent years, there has been active participation of social media users in creating awareness as well as feeding pollution-related information via several micro-blogging platforms like Twitter, Sina-Weibo, etc.  Here, we reveal some interesting initial exploratory results on inferring air quality using Twitter data.

title: Image inpainting using conditional Gaussian Mixture Models
authors: Marcin Przewięźlikowski, Marek Śmieja, Łukasz Struski
abstract: In this project we show how to estimate probability distribution of missing image parts using Gaussian densities. In contrast to a typical shallow approach, we use deep neural networks, which allows for high flexibility and avoiding computational problems.  Given an incomplete data point, our neural network returns the parameters of Gaussian distribution (in the form of Factor Analyzers model) representing the corresponding conditional density. We experimentally verify that our model provides better log-likelihood than conditional GMM trained in a typical way. Preliminary experiments performed on MNIST and CelebA demonstrate that our model is able to handle complex high dimensional data.

title: Learning robust visual representations using data augmentation invariance
authors: Alex Hernandez-Garcia, Peter König, Tim Kietzmann
abstract: The current most accurate models of image object categorization are deep neural networks trained on large labeled data sets. Minimizing a classification loss between the predictions of the network and the true labels has proven an effective way to learn discriminative functions of the object classes. However, recent studies have suggested that such models learn highly discriminative features that are not aligned with visual perception and might be at the root of adversarial vulnerability. Here, we propose to replace the classification loss with the joint optimization of invariance to identity-preserving transformations of images (data augmentation invariance), and the invariance to objects of the same category (class-wise invariance). We hypothesize that optimizing these invariance objectives might yield features more aligned with visual perception, more robust to adversarial perturbations, while still suitable for accurate object categorization.

title: Second Language Learning in Humans and Machines
authors: Anshul Gupta, Kiran Praveen, Akshara Soman, Sriram Ganapathy
abstract: Cross modal association learning has been studied for humans but questions remain on novel image-audio association. In this work, we study association learning of Japanese words given as image-audio input for human subjects. We also compare machine performance for this task. The proposed model is a deep audio-visual correspondence network that uses a proxy based triplet loss. It is pre-trained with large dataset of English speech/image input, and a subset of the parameters are transfer learned for a smaller dataset of Japanese speech/image input. We compare human and machine performance on image retrieval and contrast the errors.

title: Textural and deep learning methods in recognition of renal cancer types based on CT images
authors: Aleksandra Osowska-Kurczab, Tomasz Markiewicz, Miroslaw Dziekiewicz, Malgorzata Lorent
abstract: The aim of this work is to develop new approaches to recognition of renal cancer types on the basis of single-phase CT imaging. Two different solutions were investigated: textural descriptors passed to SVM classifier and CNN architectures. The experimental research for both textural and deep learning approaches was conducted on real world dataset of CT scans consisting of eight types of renal cell carcinomas. The proposed structure of predictive system was able to achieve the level of F1-score around 90% for complex and unbalanced dataset. Findings of the study were discussed with regard to dataset quality and preprocessing steps.

title: Recipe-Ingredient Substitution
authors: Vindhya Singh, Chinmay Prabhakar
abstract:
In order to find healthier substitutes for food items, one requires data to draw similarities. Recipe1M+ is one such data-set, provided by
Marin et al (2018). However, textually parsing and deriving similarity between the
text, contextually, is the main challenge and this is where techniques of Natural Language Processing
will be beneficial. The main motivation is to explore ways that similarities
can be found between recipe texts so as to aim for better substitution recommendations. The project
aims at building over the research being conducted presently and exploring various techniques of
NLP that can be used to bridge the gap.

title: Representing Point Clouds with Generative Conditional Invertible Flow Networks
authors: Michał Stypułkowski; Kacper Kania; Maciej Zamorski; Maciej Zięba; Tomasz Trzciński; Jan Chorowski
abstract: We propose a simple yet effective method to represent point clouds as probability distributions defined by generative neural networks. To exploit similarities between same-class objects, networks that model densities of points belonging to objects in the same family share all parameters with the exception of a small, object-specific embedding vector. We show that these embedding vectors capture semantic relationships between objects. Our method leverages generative flow networks to learn embeddings as well as to generate point clouds. Our model offers competitive or superior quantitative results while enabling capabilities to perform cloud manipulation tasks, such as registration and aligning.

title: Fetal ECG signal classification using Bag of Words approach
authors: Urszula Żuchowicz
abstract: Research proposed Bag of Word model as a representation method in bioelectrical signal analysis. The main objective of this project was to apply BoW concept to capture some specific time-series information in fetal arrhythmia classification.  Non-invasive fetal ECG recordings were characterized using wavelet transformation. HSBCSCAN clustering was applied for generating vocabulary (codewords). The classification was performed using classic types of classifiers: Support Vector Classifier and Artificial Neural Networks. Parameters affecting on classification results such as clusters  size and segment length have been also analyzed.

title: An analysis of the possibility of using ML.NET framework
authors: Romeo Rego
abstract:
Due to constantly rising amount of generated data, more and more machine learning (ML) and deep
learning (DL) solutions are implemented across companies and institutions to
deal with this issue. One of such technologies, targeted at
programmers rather than data scientists is ML.NET, a new ML framework for .NET
based applications. My aim is to review said framework thoroughly and assess
its utility by verifying whether its functionalities are sufficient to make it useful
in production, as well as to determine whether provided programming interface
makes it easy to use.

title: Security Hardening of Botnet Detectors using GANs
authors: Rizwan Hamid Randhawa
abstract: Machine learning (ML) based botnet detectors are no exception to traditional ML models when it comes to adversarial evasion attacks. The datasets used to train these models have also scarcity and unbalance issues. We propose a technique named Botshot, based on generative adversarial networks (GANs) for addressing these issues and making botnet detectors aware of adversarial evasions. Botshot is cost-effective as compared to the network emulation for botnet traffic data generation rendering the need for  dedicated hardware resources.

title: Extracting personal Information from conversations
authors: Anna Tigunova, Paramita Mirza, Andew Yates, Gerhard Weikum
abstract:
Open-domain dialogue agents must be able to converse about many
topics while incorporating knowledge about the user into the conversation.
In this work we address the acquisition of such knowledge by extracting
personal attributes from conversations. This problem is
more challenging than the established task of information extraction
from scientific publications or Wikipedia articles, because
dialogues often give merely implicit cues about the speaker. We
propose methods for inferring personal attributes, such as profession,
age or family status, from conversations using deep learning.
Specifically, we propose several Hidden Attribute Models, which are
neural networks leveraging attention mechanisms and embeddings.

title: Invariant Representations without Adversarial Training, Style Transfer
authors: Rafayel Darbinyan
abstract: Representations of data that are invariant to changes in specified factors are useful for a wide range of problems: removing potential biases in prediction problems, controlling the effects of covariates, and disentangling meaningful factors of variation. Unfortunately, learning representations that exhibit invariance to arbitrary nuisance factors yet remain useful for other tasks is challenging. Authors of the paper cast invariant representation learning as a single information-theoretic objective that can be directly optimized. Authors demonstrate that this approach matches or exceeds performance of state-of-the-art adversarial approaches. In my reproduction work I used this algorithm for style transfer for handwritten digits.

title: Proximal Policy Optimization for Improved Convergence in IRGAN
authors: Moksh Jain, Sowmya Kamath S
abstract: IRGAN is an information retrieval approach that uses a theoretical minimax game between a generative and a discriminative model to iteratively optimize both of them. IRGAN training is unstable, and the results vary largely with the random parameter initialization. In this work, we present an improved training objective based on proximal policy optimization and Gumbel-Softmax based sampling for the generator and a modified training algorithm which takes a single gradient update on both the generator as well as the discriminator for each iteration step. We present comparisons on three different IR tasks and we observed improved performance with our modifications.

title: Hierarchical reinforcement learning for efficient exploration and transfer
authors: Lorenzo Steccanella, Simone Totaro, Damien Allonsius, Anders Jonsson
abstract: Sparse-reward domains are challenging for reinforcement learning algorithms since significant exploration is needed before encountering reward for the first time. Hierarchical reinforcement learning can facilitate exploration by reducing the number of decisions necessary before obtaining a reward. In this paper, we present a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework based on the compression of an invariant state space that is common to a range of tasks. The algorithm introduces subtasks which consist in moving between the state partitions induced by the compression. Results indicate that the algorithm can successfully solve complex sparse-reward domains, and transfer knowledge.

title: Reward Redistribution Mechanisms using Multi Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Anirudha Jitani, Aly Ibrahim, Daoud Piracha, Doina Precup
abstract: In typical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) settings, each agent acts to maximize its individual reward objective. However, for collective social welfare maximization, some agents may need to act non-selfishly. We propose a reward shaping mechanism using extrinsic motivation for achieving modularity and increased cooperation among agents in Sequential Social Dilemma (SSD) problems. Our mechanism, inspired by capitalism, provides extrinsic motivation to agents by redistributing a portion of collected rewards based on each agent’s individual contribution towards team rewards. We demonstrate empirically that this mechanism leads to higher collective welfare, reduces free rider issues, and leads to more diverse policies.

title: Topic Labeling using BART-TL
authors: Cristian Popa
abstract: We propose a novel solution for assigning labels to topic models by using weak labelers. This method leverages transformer models to learn accurate representations of the most important topic terms. This is achieved by fine-tuning pre-trained transformer models on a large numbers of potential labels generated by state of the art non-neural models for topic labeling, enriched with different techniques. These labels are of varying quality, as they were meant to be ranked in subsequent steps. The proposed BART-TL model is able to distinguish the valuable labels in a weakly-supervised manner.

title: Learning Hybrid Locomotion-Manipulation Policies for Arm-on-ANYmal
authors: Mayank Mittal, Vassilios Tsounis, David Hoeller, Marco Hutter
abstract: This work considers the problem of learning policies for a mobile manipulator in partially observable domains. We consider the robot ALMA, a completely torque-controlled quadrupedal robot with a robotic arm mounted on it. We formulate the learning problem as a cooperative multi-agent system comprising of the base and the arm and extend the single-agent deep RL algorithm based on policy gradients to this setting. We show that learning based on a completely decentralized multi-agent system tends to outperform a centralized multi-agent system on a suite of cooperative control tasks that we propose in this work.

title: TrafficLight: Holistic Detection of Human Trafficking in Online Escort Advertisements
authors: Aayushi Kulshrestha, Catalina Vajiac, Sacha Levy, Junhao Wang, Namyong Park, Dhivya Eswaran, Cara Jones, Christos Faloutsos, Reihaneh Rabbany​
abstract: Can we spot human trafficking, by analyzing online escort ads? Can we explain our findings and reasoning, to law-enforcement? We propose TRAFFICLIGHT, which tackles these problems. We present TRAFFICLIGHT- an unsupervised, generalized approach that finds suspiciously connected cases of organized activity in escort ads and summarizes the evidence for a faster investigation.  TRAFFICLIGHT provides easily interpretable summarized results,  with an  estimated25x speedup in the detection of such criminal groups.  With a  further meta-clustering,  that is,  grouping clusters of ads,  we detected several M.O.s (modus operandi = types of behaviors) - the most striking one was the ‘smoke screen’ behavior.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Congestion Control via a Flexible Action Adjustment
authors: Chen-Yu Yen, Soheil Abbasloo, Jonathan Chao
abstract: Congestion control is critical to achieving low latency, high throughput, and reliability in computer networks. With new technologies in the networked system every year, new approaches are proposed to do a better job of controlling congestion and satisfying the new demand for emerging applications. We introduce a deep reinforcement learning framework for congestion control to boost existing schemes instead of reinventing or replacing them. Our agent automatically adapts existing congestion control schemes to cellular network environments, for which those schemes are not originally designed. We demonstrate how to develop DRL methods in complex network environments.

title: The k-tied Normal Distribution: A Compact Parameterization of Gaussian Mean Field Posteriors in Bayesian Neural Networks
authors: Jakub Swiatkowski, Kevin Roth, Bastiaan Veeling, Linh Tran, Joshua Dillon, Jasper Snoek, Stephan Mandt, Tim Salimans, Rodolphe Jenatton, Sebastian Nowozin
abstract: Variational Bayesian Inference is a popular methodology for approximating posterior distributions over Bayesian neural network weights. Recent work has explored ever richer parameterizations of the approximate posterior. In contrast, here we study an opposite direction of more compact parameterizations. For a variety of deep Bayesian neural networks trained using Gaussian mean-field variational inference, we find that the posterior standard deviations consistently exhibit strong low-rank structure after convergence. This allows us to compress the variational approximation without decreasing the models' performance. Furthermore, we find that such factorized parameterizations improve the signal-to-noise ratio of stochastic gradient estimates, resulting in faster convergence.

title: Self-Supervised Learning of Rapid Maneuver Planning for Car-Like Vehicles
authors: Piotr Kicki, Tomasz Gawron, Piotr Skrzypczyński
abstract:
We introduce a novel neural network-based method for path planning,
which employs a gradient-based self-supervised learning algorithm to predict feasible paths.
The proposed approach strongly exploits the experience gained in the past and rapidly yields feasible maneuver plans for car-like vehicles with limited steering-angle.
The effectiveness of such an approach has been confirmed by computational experiments.

title: Book Characters as Library Assistants
authors: Ariel Lubonja, BA;  Laura Tolosi, PhD
abstract: The vision of the USC Library is to have AI-powered assistants that visitors can talk to, thus offering a modern experience and an innovative interaction with the world of books. We present a chatbot depicting the character Alice from the book The Adventures of Alice in Wonderland by Lewis Carroll. A speech recognition system translates users' spoken questions to text and a question answering system based on BERT is providing the requested information (i.e. facts from the book, biographical information on Lewis Carroll and his work, and some topics about the USC LIbrary).

title: Normalizing Flows for Approximating Probability Densities
authors: David Liu, Lukas Ryll, Vincent Stimper
abstract: Rezende and Mohamed in [1] approximate complex distributions by transforming an initial simple distribution through invertible mappings called normalizing flows. They propose two particular types of flows, planar and radial, and show their expressivity in a variational inference setting. In this work, I reproduce their main results on approximating 2D toy probability densities, and compare their proposed flows with NICE [2], RealNVP [3] and Glow [4]. Normalizing flows are found to be able to approximate complex multimodal distributions in a 2D setting.

title: Dense 3D Reconstruction and Object Pose Estimation
authors: Dinh-Cuong Hoang
abstract: This work presents a system for accurate 3D instance-aware semantic reconstruction and 6D pose estimation, using an RGB-D camera. The framework couples convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and a state-of-the-art dense SimultaneousLocalization and Mapping system, ElasticFusion, to achieve both high-quality semantic reconstruction as well as robust 6D pose estimation for relevant objects. While the main trend in CNN-based 6D pose estimation has been to infer object’s position and orientation from single views of the scene, the proposed approach explores performing pose estimation from multiple viewpoints, under the conjecture that combining multiple predictions can improve the robustness of an object detection system.

title: Experimental design for MRI by greedy policy search
authors: Tim Bakker, Herke van Hoof, Max Welling
abstract: MRI is routinely accelerated through subsampling of the associated Fourier domain, but the subsampling currently relies on heuristics. We propose to learn experimental design strategies for accelerated MRI with policy gradients. Unexpectedly, our experiments show that a greedy approximation of the objective leads to better solutions than the more general non-greedy approach. We propose an explanation for this phenomenon rooted in the greater presence of noise in the non-greedy objective’s gradients, and verify that this noise leaves the non-greedy models unable to adapt their policies to individual MR images. We show that this adaptivity is key to improving subsampling designs.

title: Violence Detection and Localization in Surveillance Video
authors: David Choqueluque Roman, Guillermo Cámara Chávez
abstract: Automatic violence detection in video surveillance is very important for social and personal security. Due to the massive video data produced by surveillance cameras installed in different environments like airports, trains, stadiums, schools, etc., traditional video monitoring by humans operators becomes inefficient. In this context, develop systems capable of detect automatically violent actions is a challenge task. This work describes a method to detect and localize violent actions in video surveillance using dynamic images, CNN's and weakly supervised localization methods. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our method when applied to two public benchmarks, Hockey Fight and UCFCrime2Local datasets.

title: Single Agent’s Adventures in Google Football Environment by means of Reinforcement Learning
authors: Maciej Mikuła, Mikołaj Pacek, Mateusz Rychlicki
abstract:
Google Research Football is a novel Reinforcement Learning environment simulator of the game of football. In GRF paper, the best training result is obtained using a graphical observation in the form of a 2D ’mini-map’ representing the football pitch.
Our project aimed to test the possibility of using alternative observations: floating-point vectors. We developed training protocols, which achieved results better than in the original GRF paper.
In our project, we introduce and evaluate four different training algorithms to systematically increase the training challenge. Our best agent managed to beat sophisticated agents trained by the Google Brain Team in public leaderboard.

title: Reference Trajectory Prediction for Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Michał Martyniak
abstract:
This poster presents a simple autonomous driving system consisting of three separable modules: perception, planning and control. 

The most important aspect of all the work done concerns the planning module. 
Proposed method of predicting so called reference trajectory was implemented and evaluated in CARLA simulation environment.
The model takes two inputs: an image from RGB camera and a navigation command. Output is a road trajectory, several meters long. 

Steering signals are produced outside neural network, using two PID controllers. 
This leads to much better understanding of agent’s actions in comparison with common method of predicting a single steering angle.

title: Neural Network-based Estimation of Fuel Consumption of a Conventional Delivery Vehicle based on GPS and CAN-collected Big Data
authors: Mislav Hihlik
abstract: In the last few decades, extensive effort has been put in fuel consumption modelling of commercial vehicles. The work done on this project has a threefold aim:  (i) fuel consumption modelling based on deep NNs which uses recorded driving cycles as input, (ii) proposing the driving cycle pre-processing method that provides proper inputs to NNs and takes payload mass in account, and (iii) validation of the prediction accuracy of the obtained NN-based fuel consumption models and their verification through comparison with the simple polynomial and simulation models.

title: Image-to-image translation based face de-occlusion
authors: Rahul S. Maharjan, Nizam Ud Din, Junho Yi
abstract:
Existing deep learning-based object removal methods produce plausible results. However, they generate unsatisfactory
results when the object is large. Most of these methods rely on the object information in terms of a binary map which is insufficient to provide
information about the face semantics relation. To address the problem, we propose a two-stage
GAN-based image-to-image translation method that exploits the face semantic segmentation. Specifically, our model learns a complete facial segmentation map from an input image
in the first stage and translates that generated semantic segmentation map combined with input image into a plausible face image without the object.

title: Geometric properties of adversarial images
authors: Bogdan Ivanyuk-Skulskiy; Galyna Kriukova; Andrii Dmytryshyn
abstract: Machine learning models are now widely used in a variety of tasks. However, they are vulnerable to adversarial perturbations. These are slight, intentionally worst-case, modifications to input that change the model's prediction with high confidence, without causing a human eye to spot a difference from real samples. The detection of adversarial samples is an open problem. In this work, we explore a novel method towards adversarial image detection with linear algebra approach. This method is built on a comparison of distances to the centroids for a given point and its neighbours.

title: Model-Based Reinforcement Learning with Deep Generative Models for Industrial Applications
authors: Ângelo Gregório Lovatto, Thiago Pereira Bueno, Leliane Nunes de Barros
abstract: RL agents can automate industrial systems, e.g., gas turbines and HVAC scheduling, and potentially outperform traditional methods. Such systems have high usage costs, so sample-efficiency is of paramount importance. Our work proposes developing model-based RL solutions that tackle the efficiency problem in this domain. Given the highly stochastic and multimodal nature of these systems' dynamics, we offer two approaches. One is via deep generative models capable of modeling these distributions. The other is decision-aware model learning, which avoids learning accurate models by prioritizing performance in the decision-making task. We aim to identify which is more promising for real industrial applications.

title: H-Mem: Harnessing synaptic plasticity with Hebbian Memory Networks
authors: Thomas Limbacher and Robert Legenstein
abstract: The ability to base current computations on memories from the past is critical for many cognitive tasks such as story understanding. Hebbian-type synaptic plasticity is believed to underlie the retention of memories over medium and long time scales in the brain. However, it is unclear how such plasticity processes are integrated with computations in cortical networks. Here, we propose Hebbian Memory Networks (H-Mems), a simple neural network model that is built around a core hetero-associative network subject to Hebbian plasticity. We show that the network can be optimized to utilize the Hebbian plasticity processes for its computations. H-Mems can one-shot memorize associations between stimulus pairs and use these associations for decisions later on. Furthermore, they can solve demanding question-answering tasks on synthetic stories. Our study shows that  neural network models are able to enrich their computations with memories through simple Hebbian plasticity processes.

title: Concept Saliency Maps to Visualize Relevant Features in Deep Generative Models
authors: Lennart Brocki, Neo Christopher Chung
abstract:
While saliency maps may help identify relevant features
(e.g., pixels) in the input for classification tasks of deep neural
networks, similar frameworks are understudied in unsupervised
learning. Therefore, we introduce a new method of obtaining
saliency maps for latent representations of known or novel highlevel concepts, often called concept vectors in generative models.
Concept scores, analogous to class scores in classification tasks,
are defined as dot products between concept vectors and encoded
input data, which can be readily used to compute the gradients.
The resulting concept saliency maps are shown to highlight
input features deemed important for high-level concepts.

title: Book Characters as Library Assistants
authors: Laura Tolosi, Ariel Lubonja
abstract: The vision of the USC Library is to have AI-powered assistants that visitors can talk to, thus offering a modern experience and an innovative interaction with the world of books. We present a chatbot depicting the character Alice from the book The Adventures of Alice in Wonderland by Lewis Carroll. A speech recognition system translates users' spoken questions to text and a question answering system based on BERT is providing the requested information (i.e. facts from the book, biographical information on Lewis Carroll and his work, and some topics about the USC LIbrary).

title: Synthetic18K: Learning Better Representations for Person Re-ID and Attribute Recognition from 1.4 Million Synthetic Images
authors: Onur Can Uner, Cem Aslan, Burak Ercan, Tayfun Ates, Ufuk Celikcan, Aykut Erdem, Erkut Erdem
abstract: Learning robust representations is important for person re-identification and attribute recognition systems. This requires to use a large dataset of diverse person images with annotations, which is costly, and introduces privacy issues. In this paper, we instead propose to use synthetic person images. Specifically, we first introduce Synthetic18K, a large-scale dataset of over 1 million computer-generated person images of 18K unique identities. Moreover, we demonstrate that pretraining of simple deep architectures on Synthetic18K for these tasks and then fine-tuning on real data leads to significant improvements in prediction performances, giving results better than or comparable to state-of-the-art models.

title: Quasi-Multitask Learning
authors: Norbert Kis-Szabó; Gábor Berend
abstract: We propose the technique of quasi-multitask learning (Q-MTL), a simple variant of multitask learning, in which the tasks to be modelled are identical. The proposed architecture can be regarded as a new regularization technique encouraging the model to develop an internal representation of the problem at hand that is beneficial to multiple output units of the classifier at the same time. Our experiments corroborate that by relying on the proposed algorithm, we can approximate the quality of an ensemble of classifiers at a fraction of computational resources required.

title: Using fastText on Semantic Networks
authors: Markéta Masopustová
abstract: Semantic networks were developed to help machine translation or artificial intelligence. They centre words with similar meaning close together. This approach is parallel to clustering in machine learning, where similar values create clusters. However, those clusters do not have to be the same ones as in semantic networks. In our project, we aim to compare those clusters.

title: Method of mobile robot local collision avoidance based on deep reinforcement learning
authors: Bartłomiej Olechno
abstract: Local collision avoidance is responsible for choosing proper velocities control signals for an engine driver. Current local collision avoidance is based on a robot dynamic model and a heuristic function that can grade simulated future states of the robot. Sub-optimal control caused by heuristic function and not precise model is the main reason for worthiness of the application of the reinforcement learning-based algorithm in a local collision avoidance task. Described research is concentrated on the training of the reinforcement learning-based controller for a single Turtlebot mobile robot in the Gazebo simulator. Results were compared with the standard algorithm.

title: Sentiment Analysis of Sinhala News Comments
authors: Surangika Ranathunga, Isuru Liyanage
abstract: This paper presents a case-study on the effectiveness of word embedding techniques for sentiment analysis in the low resource language Sinhala. We experimented with both fastText and Word2Vec. In both cases, skipgram model with 300D gave the optimal result. fastText outperformed Word2Vec and other features such as TF-IDF for both binary(POSITIVE/NEGATIVE) and multi-class (POSITIVE/NEGATIVE/NEUTRAL) classification with Logistic Regression, SVM, and vanilla LSTM. This is due to its ability to be robust to the highly inflectional nature of Sinhala, as it operates at sub-word level.

title: Generating balanced multiplayer game levels with GANs and RL
authors: Grzegorz Opoka
abstract: In this work we present a novel approach, combining a modified GAN framework with RL agents, to generate balanced multiplayer game levels. In our experiments, we have created a basic racing game with artificial players varying in skill and strategy. Our level generator is able to create a fair racetracks that do not favor any player.

title: BacterOMIC: Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing Enhanced By Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Michał Bortkiewicz, Krystian Kurek and Paweł Dębski, PhD
abstract: In this work, we show how analytical methods based on machine learning can support novel solutions in the area of medical diagnostics and in particular the determination of antimicrobial susceptibility to antibiotics. BacterOMIC uses ML methods to observe the incubation chambers, improve the quality of collected data and its classification. Here, we present unsupervised anomaly detection method and briefly report most important results. We focus on the recognition and classification of optical disturbances that are created as a result of microbial metabolism and may alter the results of susceptibility test.

title: Learning SAT Encodings for Constraint Satisfaction Problems
authors: Felix Ulrich-Oltean
abstract: I present a summary of my PhD research area, Constraint Satisfaction Problems.  I give a motivating example and a brief overview of CSPs, I explain how translation to SAT can help in finding solutions quickly and I outline some preliminary experiments which support the direction of my research to use machine learning to make fine-grained encoding choices for unseen CSPs.

title: Autonomous Navigation Scenario Simulation through RL Learning
authors: Bogdan Vajdea
abstract: The policy optimization implemented in the reinforcement learning method, used in the development of an autonomous navigation scenario, is the main innovation factor in building dedicated simulation environments. The issues addressed in the development of this project are: the functioning of the policy optimization algorithm (PPO) and its implementation in the current scenario, the training of machine learning agents, the autonomous navigation and the constraints used for its realization, the further development of a complex simulation system autonomous navigation.

title: One-class Classification for Personal Risk Detection
authors: Ari Yair Barrera-Animas, Luis A. Trejo, Jorge Rodríguez, Miguel Angel Medina-Pérez, and Raúl Monroy
abstract: In this research work, a new approach based on wearable sensors namely Personal Risk Detection is proposed. We defined Personal Risk Detection as the timely identification of when someone is in a dangerous situation, such as a health crisis or car accident, or other events that may endanger a person’s physical integrity. A publicly available dataset named PRIDE was built from 23 users under normal and abnormal conditions. A new one-class classification algorithm designed to run on devices with limited resources and that nowadays stands out as the state-of-the-art classifier for personal risk detection is introduced.

title: Bag of Local Convolutional Features for Invariant Visual Object Recognition
authors: Jaspreet Singh
abstract: Although convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have proven to be very powerful tool for various computer vision applications. CNNs are still impotent to handle geometric transformations such as rotation, reflection and translation which are inevitable case for the task of image classification. Data augmentation is one of the most intuitive solutions to achieve invariance. However, it does not guarantee invariance. In this paper we propose a framework to derive the features invariant to rotation and reflection by using bag of local convolutional feature maps. Further, the proposed geometric invariant framework is evaluated on three object recognition datasets.

title: Evaluation of Character-Level Predictive Language Models
authors: Konrad Bereda, Łukasz Cesarski
abstract: Substantial part of commercial NLP products is successfully powered by word-level language models, but they are not without flaws. The closed vocabulary problem is the main reason of their failures. Limited in size dictionary is enough for English, but is not sufficient for languages with more complex morphology like agglutinative and fusional ones, commonly used in Eastern Europe. Moreover, constructing a vocabulary list is extremely laborious as it involves expertise of linguists and developers. In this paper, we examine the feasibility of using fully character-level neural networks for language model that should be able to overcome the above limitations.

title: Electronic Design Automation using Deep Learning
authors: S. Indrapriyadarsini, Shahrzad Mahboubi, Hiroshi Ninomiya, Takeshi Kamio, Hideki Asai
abstract: With the rising need for high-performance circuits, electronic design automation (EDA) has gained significant attention. Deep learning for EDA has lead to significant improvements in solution quality and speeding the design time and process. Gradient based algorithms are popular in training deep neural networks (DNNs). In this work, we propose a second order Nesterov's accelerated quasi-Newton method for training DNNs and show its efficiency in EDA applications such as electromagnetic modelling and analog circuit design optimization using DNN and physical design automation using deep reinforcement learning.

title: Sub-second structure of motivated behaviours regulated by the neurotensin brain circuitry
authors: Hanna E. van den Munkhof, Francisco B. de los Santos, Tatiana Korotkova
abstract:
Here we apply MoSeq, an unsupervised machine learning algorithm, on depth images to automatically classify mouse behaviour with sub-second precision. 

To elucidate the role of neural circuitry in motivation, we activate neurons expressing neurotensin in lateral hypothalamus (LHA) or lateral septum (LS) -part of the reward system- using chemogenetics, while mice engage in motivated behaviours such as feeding and social interaction. 

LHA activation increased consummatory behaviour, while decreasing exploratory behaviour. LS activation had a general opposite effect. These results suggest that neurotensin neurons selectively regulate behaviour related to consumption and exploration, with differential effects depending on brain area.

title: Reproduction of DPOD: 6D pose detector and refiner
authors: Mateusz Olko
abstract: The goal of this work is to reproduce DPOD: 6D Pose Object Detector and Refiner paper. In this experiment, RGB images and 3D models of objects are used to retrieve translation relative to the camera and rotations in all three axes. The method is a combination of Neural Network and algorithmic approach. It utilizes so-called correspondence mappings. The mappings are obtained by projecting 3D object points to a cylinder and assigning a color to the point based on the projection coordinates. They allow an efficient pose detection procedure.

title: Permutation-free CGMM: Complex Gaussian mixture model with inverse Wishart mixture model based spatial prior for permutation-free source separation and source counting
authors: Juan Azcarreta, Nobutaka Ito, Shoko Araki, Tomohiro Nakatani
abstract: We propose a permutation-free cGMM for audio source separation, a new probabilistic model, which can resolve permutation ambiguity between frequency bins, and is applicable even when the number of sources is unknown. A recently proposed complex Gaussian mixture model (cGMM) is highly effective for frequency bin-wise clustering when the number of sources is known, but it cannot resolve the permutation ambiguity. To tackle this problem, we extend the cGMM method with a spatial prior called a complex inverse Wishart mixture model over the possible directions of arrival. The absence of the permutation ambiguity facilitates source counting.

title: Motivated agent with semantic memory
authors: M. Kowalik, J. Starzyk, A. Horzyk
abstract: An motivated learning (ML) agent operates in a dynamically changing environment in which he is able to create and achieve his own goals, including the goals set by the designer. The environment is represented by a graph that incorporates the principles that rule in the environment. By exploring the environment, the agent learns these principles. The ML agent with memory can use additional knowledge about the environment represented in associative semantic memory and he is able to achieve his goals faster. This memory is based on ANAKG associative knowledge graphs.

title: NeatSkin: A Discrete Impedance Tomography Skin Sensor
authors: Euan Judd, Krishna Manaswi Digumarti, Jonathan Rossiter, Helmut Hauser
abstract: NeatSkin is an artificial skin sensor used to infer the location of touch employing discrete impedance tomography and machine learning.

title: Automatic Parking with Q-Learning
authors: Leonardo Lai
abstract:
Automatic parking is one of the fundamental challenges on the path towards self-driving vehicles.
In this work I show how a reinforcement learning method, namely Q-learning, can be used to deal with the problem of automatic parking. 
The algorithm is then implemented in a simulated environment to prove its effectiveness.

title: Summix- Automated Privacy Policy Analyzer and Summarizer
authors: Shahzeb Ali
abstract: TBD

title: Theft Car Surveillance using Multi-level Deep Learning Classification
authors: Aqsa Hassan, Mohsin Ali, Nouman Durrani, M A Tahir
abstract: A multi-level system has been proposed to deal with the problem of fake license plates by integrating ALPR along with recognition of different other features such as vehicle color, make and model. YOLOv3 is applied for vehicle type detection and WPOD-NET is employed to rectify detected license plates, which are fed to an OCR. Several promising CNNs have also been trained and tested using Stanford Cars-196 dataset where Xception outperformed previous approaches with 96.7% accuracy. A novel deep neural network for vehicle color recognition has also been implemented, which is not only computationally inexpensive, but also outperforms other competitive methods.

title: Audio-driven Robot Upper-body Motion Synthesis
authors: Jan Ondras, Oya Celiktutan, Paul Bremner and Hatice Gunes
abstract: Robotic platforms are often limited in their ability to generate behaviours that align with their speech. In this project, we developed an NN-based system that inputs audio from a user and generates upper-body gestures including head, hand, and torso movements of the user on a humanoid robot Pepper. Our system was evaluated quantitatively as well as qualitatively using web-surveys when driven by natural speech and synthetic speech. We compared the impact of various NN models on the quality of synthesised movements, investigated the relationships between quantitative and qualitative evaluations, and examined how the speaker’s personality traits affect the synthesised movements.

title: Local Climate Zones semantic segmentation using encoder-decoder neural network U-Net
authors: Vitaliy Kinakh(1) , Rostyslav Bun (1, 2)
abstract:
Local climate zones (LCZ) are digital maps that describe the urban surface structure and cover with consistency and comparability across cities. In this paper, we present the results of data collection and the semantic segmentation of LCZ for Europe. We collect training images using Google Earth Engine, training labels from the WUDAPT data portal, and use deep learning framework fast.ai for model design and semantic segmentation experiments.
Local climate zones (LCZ) supervised classification (segmentation) using satellite remote sensing images and deep learning algorithms is a promising research field because there is a lot of data, which is generated on a regular basis and there is a huge demand for automatic data classification.

title: Hyperspectral Imaging for Real-time Classification of Skin Lesions
authors: Ioannis Gkouzionis
abstract: Hyperspectral imaging (HSI) is an emerging non-invasive detection technology able to reveal critical information that conventional imaging systems may not be able to deliver. This research study aims at defining strategies for the analysis of HS images, placing the focal point on the investigation of techniques for the classification of spatio-spectral information. Dimensionality reduction is applied to reduce redundancies, while unsupervised classification is utilised to discriminate between benign and malignant tissue and feed a binary linear supervised classifier. The proposed framework has the potential to assist clinicians in quantifying pigmented skin lesions.

title: EfficientDet Reproduction in PyTorch
authors: Vsevolod Konyakhin
abstract:
Tremendous work has been done in recent years towards real-time object
detection. In March 2020, Google Brain Team has released source code for
EfficientDet, Scalable and Efficient Object Detection, written in TensorFlow. In
this extended abstract, I propose a PyTorch implementation of EfficientDet that
reproduces results from the original paper. To the best of my knowledge, I am the
first one to achieve state-of-the-art training on COCO dataset in PyTorch. Source
code is publicly available at https://github.com/sevakon/efficientdet

title: CAN AUTO-ENCODERS HELP WITH FILLING MISSING DATA?
authors: Marek Śmieja, Maciej Kołomycki, Łukasz Struski, Mateusz Juda, Mario A. T. Figueiredo
abstract:
This paper introduces an approach to filling in missing data based on deep autoencoder models, adequate to high-dimensional data exhibiting complex dependencies, such as images. The method exploits the properties of auto-encoders’ vector
fields, which allows to approximate the gradient of the log-density from its reconstruction error, based on which we propose a projected gradient ascent algorithm
to obtain the conditionally most probable estimate of the missing values. Experiments performed on benchmark datasets show that imputations produced by our
model are sharp and realistic.

title: Quantum-based machine learning investigation of Au(III)-catalysts for acetylene functionalization
authors: Vladimir Levchenko, Ainara Nova, David Balcells and Mats Tilset
abstract: In this work, a data-driven study of the chemical space of cyclometalated Au(III) acetates is presented. For this purpose, we combined quantum mechanic computations (DFT) and ML to enable the prediction of reactivity within large chemical space containing thousands of Au(III)-complexes in the catalytic acetylene functionalization. In the space of 1000 complexes derived from cyclometalated Au(III)-complexes, data from DFT calculations are used to train and test ML models that predict the acetylene insertion energies. We successfully combined Bayesian-optimised artificial neural networks (ANN) with features derived from circular Morgan fingerprints. The resulting ANNs achieved high accuracies, with mean absolute errors (MAE) less than 1 kcal/mol.

title: Reproducing the Results of "Deep Learning without Weight Transport"
authors: Vanja Doskoč
abstract:
Deep learning algorithms, while devised to run on computers, are fairly similar to the human brain. While both use multilayer networks of processing units, a deep learning algorithm relies on error-backpropagation which utilizes a weight transport. A mechanism which the brain cannot rely on.

Many attempts to circumvent this transport of weights have been made. In the reviewed paper, weight mirroring is proposed as a way to learn more complex tasks without  the need of weight transport: The weights are reconstructed solely from information given by the nodes of the network.

title: Detecting CNN-Generated Facial Images in Real-World Scenarios
authors: Nils Hulzebosch, Sarah Ibrahimi, Marcel Worring
abstract: Artificial, CNN-generated images are now of such high quality that humans have trouble distinguishing them from real images. Several algorithmic detection methods have been proposed, but these appear to generalize poorly to data from unknown sources, making them infeasible for real-world scenarios. We present a framework for evaluating detection methods under real-world conditions and we evaluate state-of-the-art detection methods using this framework. Furthermore, we examine the usefulness of image pre-processing methods. Lastly, we evaluate human performance on detecting CNN-generated images. Our results suggest that CNN-based detection methods are not yet robust enough to be used in real-world scenarios.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Networks for Power Systems
authors: Jochen Stiasny
abstract: We explore how physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) can provide a tool to support the transition of power systems towards carbon-neutrality. With PINNs we obtain an explicit function approximation of the solution to the governing highly non-linear differential equations. Compared with traditional solvers this results in a considerable speed-up of the solution time. By using the underlying physics in the training process, we furthermore circumvent the need for historical or simulated data. In case we do have measured data, PINNs can also serve as an estimator to system states and parameters without a change in the PINNs basic structure.

title: Define recommendations of interaction between teacher and student in the Kutubee Interactive Reading Platform using Machine learning
authors: Oksana Zavada
abstract:
The primary research of the project aims to predict a change in the educational trajectory of the reader, based solely on indicators of his behavior: the time and duration of reading, divide of suggestions of readings given by the teacher, and selected by the student. 
The project is based on genuine, not simulated, data collected over two years of SaaS from "CourseYard".
The tasks facing us:
    - analyzing the correlation between contents and speed score of reading, amount of reading, book popularity, the probability to be finished
    - student attrition and dropout, page referrals, learning delays, progression problems, failure, assignment completions, bias
    - user's target recommendation for reading

title: YOLACT: Real Time Instance Segmentation
authors: Daniel Bolya , Chong Zhou , Fanyi Xiao, and Yong Jae Lee
abstract:
YOLACT is a Real Time Instance Segmentation Method. First, it extracts features using a fully convolutional backbone, then passes them to a Feature Pyramid Network that acts as a single shot object detector. Similarly to RetinaNet, this architecture has multi-level prediction. Each level prediction is composed of 3 parts: a class prediction head, the box regressor head, and a Mask Coefficient.
In this second part, YOLACT uses prototypes, which actually feature maps generated by a Protonet Architecture. Then, for each anchor detected, these prototypes are then combined with the masking coefficients and are added to form a mask.

title: Image Quality Mapping with Explicit Modeling of Linear and Gamma Corrections
authors: Jelena Trisovic, supervised by Dr. Radu Timofte
abstract: Existing approaches to end-to-end image enhancement use standard convolutional network architectures and rely on their  complex structures to learn mappings from low- to high-quality image domains. In this work, we model such mappings by adding specialized blocks that incorporate a priori knowledge about these domains. We introduce linear and gamma connections as such blocks and use them to capture the color mapping and hence reallocate the capacity of the convolutional network to only take care of super-resolution.  After  evaluating  multiple  network structures, we reveal that the occurrence of artifacts is reduced and perceptual quality improved in comparison to existing approaches.

title: G2P and ASR for low-resource phonetic transcription of Tagalog, Cebuano, and Hiligaynon
authors: Angelina Aquino, Joshua Lijandro Tsang, Crisron Rudolf Lucas, Franz de Leon
abstract: Philippine linguists are tasked with documenting over 170 indigenous languages. A key part of this documentation is phonetic transcription, which is typically done by hand, and is often expensive and time-consuming. Automated phonetic transcribers provide an alternative to manual transcription, but no such system has yet been developed for most Philippine languages. In this project, we implement three methods—grapheme-to-phoneme conversion, automatic speech recognition, and adaptive alignment—for transcription of small speech corpora in Tagalog, Cebuano, and Hiligaynon. We show that the G2P, adaptive, and select ASR models perform at par with human transcribers while greatly reducing total time and costs.

title: Proximal Policy Optimization paper review
authors: Alvaro Caudéran
abstract:
In this paper, I will talk about the Reproduction / Implementation of the 2017 paper
on Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) published by OpenAI. I will briefly present
the original paper main ideas, discuss my results, and compare them with the original
paper results. Finally, I’m going to make a brief critic on how readable/reproducible I
found the paper to be.

title: Identifying MITRE ATT&CK Techniques in Cybersecurity Text
authors: Vlad Cîncean
abstract: In a cyberattack, the tactics, techniques and procedures (also known in the literature as TTPs) describe the adversary's behaviour. Knowing them is useful both in the process of creating defensive solutions and taking the necessary measures for the prevention of such cyber attacks. We propose to create a text classifier that, given some cybersecurity text, it identifies the adversarial techniques (as defined by ATT&CK) described in it. The approach uses an aggregation of RNNs built under the one-vs-all paradigm. A confusion matrix is used to evaluate the classifier's performance.

title: Deep learning of liquid crystal operation
authors: Dominik Vašinka, Martin Bielak and Miroslav Ježek
abstract: Polarization states of light play a vital role in many applications in optical communications, photonic information processing, optical metrology, as well as many others, and therefore a fast and precise method of their preparation and detection is required. Nematic liquid crystals present an essential method, although with a downside of limited precision. In our work, we aim to eliminate this obstacle and the presented deep neural network model enhanced fidelity up to 99.996 %. Moreover, we demonstrate the benefits of deep neural networks in comparison with the analytical description and dataset interpolation.

title: An interpretable graph classification solution for a neuroscience use case
authors: Daniela Palcu, Assoc. Prof. Dr. Camelia Lemnaru, Prof. Dr. Mihaela Dinsoreanu, Prof. Dr. Rodica Potolea.
abstract: The interpretability of Graph Convolutional Networks is significantly more challenging than for image based convolutional networks, because graphs do not exhibit clear spatial relations between their nodes. We proposed an approach for estimating the discriminative power of graph nodes from the model learned by a deep graph convolutional method. To do this, we adapt the Grad-CAM algorithm by replacing the part which heavily relies on the 2D spatial relation of pixels in an image, with an estimate of the node importance by its appearance count in the result of the Grad-CAM. We applied our solution to a neuroscience use case.

title: The application of optimization theory and reinforcement machine learning algorithms for finding a trading strategy for the agent and maximizing its profit based on data from the Steam community market. A genetic algorithm was used to optimize the baseline decision strategy, and deep Q-table and Actor-Critic algorithms were used to explore new decision-making strategies for agents.
authors: Volodymyr Mudryi
abstract: The application of optimization theory and reinforcement machine learning algorithms for finding a trading strategy for the agent and maximizing its profit based on data from the Steam community market. A genetic algorithm was used to optimize the baseline decision strategy, and deep Q-table and Actor-Critic algorithms were used to explore new decision-making strategies for agents.

title: Mutual help (in)valuable - how machine learning supports molecular modeling approaches and vice versa
authors: Sabina Podlewska, Rafał Kafel, Rafał Kurczab
abstract: Computational methods are now indispensable part of drug design process, being used at its all stages . Effectiveness of various computational methods vary depending on the target, already available ligands and method settings. Here, we carefully examined ML predictions obtained for opioid receptors (mu, kappa, delta). We did not focus on global prediction efficiency, but carefully analyzed single cases with attempts to explain prediction errors. Moreover, we tried to develop general rules for applicability of particular approach (ML-based, structure-based or combined). Finally, we also determined the similarity threshold below which, the usage of structure-based strategy is recommended.

title: Finding transferable sub-policies using meta-learning
authors: David Kuric
abstract: In reinforcement learning, policies might not transfer well between tasks because they are too specific. However, different tasks often have similar sub-tasks and thus, transfer of sub-policies that form solutions to sub-tasks may be promising. In these cases, it is crucial to set a correct size for sub-tasks in order to ensure that they are both reusable and allow for fast adaptation to multiple tasks. In our work we aim to find this task to sub-task division and to learn corresponding sub-policies by optimizing for post-adaptation performance on many tasks. We perform experiments in simple domain with satisfying preliminary results.

title: Jaccard index-Based Assessing the Similarity of Research Fields in Dimensions
authors: Mykola Petrychko, Serhiy Shtovba
abstract: We calculated the similarity of 10878 pairs of the research fields for 2010-2019 and for 2000-2009 on the base of Dimensions data. The similarity of the research fields is assessed by the Jaccard index. The most tied research fields for 2010-2019 are Specialist Studies in Education and Curricular and Pedagogy, whereas this pair holds rank #6 for 2000-2009. The dynamics of Jaccard index distributions do not confirm a hypothesis about increasing the share of interdisciplinary research over time. It is detected that the most collaborated research field for both time intervals is Mechanical Engineering.

title: Towards an Adversarially Robust Normalization Approach
authors: Muhammad Awais, Fahad Shamshad, Sung-Ho Bae
abstract: BatchNorm is effective for improving and accelerating the training of deep neural networks. However, it has also shown to be a cause of adversarial vulnerability. In this work, we investigate how BatchNorm causes this vulnerability. We first observe that adversarial images tend to shift the distribution of BatchNorm input, and this shift makes train-time estimated population statistics inaccurate. We hypothesize that these inaccurate statistics make models with BatchNorm more vulnerable. We prove our hypothesis by replacing train-time estimated statistics with statistics calculated from the inference-time batch. We found that the adversarial vulnerability of BatchNorm disappears if we use these statistics.

title: Travel behavior prediction based on ML classifiers and discrete choice models
authors: Szymon Wójcik
abstract: In this study, we tried to compare the predictive accuracy of the binary logistic regression model and four other supervised ML classifiers. The models were applied to travel behavior 2012 data of the citizens of Łódź, Poland. Binary logistic regression predictors were chosen based on theory and statistical significance tests. The outcomes show that the best accuracy was obtained for the Decision Tree method and the worst for Naive Bayes. Logistic regression model results were comparable with Neural Network and Support Vector Machines.

title: Few shot learning by features adaptation with Graph Neural Networks
authors: Armand Nicolicioiu, Andrei Nicolicioiu
abstract: In few-shot setting the goal is to solve tasks involving a small number of labelled samples while avoiding overfitting. We propose a method for few-shot classification using architectures that are biassed to model relations between the classes by using graph neural networks. We adapt intermediate query embeddings based on their interactions with support set prototypes. In preliminary  experiments  we  show  that  modulating  the features  with  graph  models  improves  multiple  backbones trained in different ways.

title: Implementation of Contrastive Predictive Coding
authors: Oana-Iuliana Popescu
abstract: Contrastive Predictive Coding (CPC) of van den Oord et al. is a technique for extracting meaningful representations from unlabeled data inspired by the theory of Predictive Coding. CPC has been applied to different modalities such as speech, natural language, and images and has obtained impressive results. This poster presents the implementation and evaluation of representation learning with CPC on image data using the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets.

title: A Deep Learning Approach to Space Weather Forecasting for Orbital Prediction
authors: Emma Stevenson, Victor Rodriguez-Fernandez, Edmondo Minisci, David Camacho
abstract:
In this work, the novel deep learning architecture N-BEATS is employed for the forecasting of space weather proxies relevant to orbital prediction. This state-of-the-art framework uses an untailored, purely machine learning approach, which has been shown to outperform existing statistical hybrid models in the field of time series forecasting, and shows promising preliminary results.
Key words: Deep Learning, Time Series Forecasting, Space Weather, Space Debris

title: Translating Visual Art into Music
authors: Max Müller-Eberstein and Nanne van Noord
abstract: The Synesthetic Variational Autoencoder (SynVAE) introduced in this research is able to learn a consistent mapping between visual and auditive sensory modalities in the absence of paired datasets. A quantitative evaluation on MNIST as well as the Behance Artistic Media dataset (BAM) shows that SynVAE is capable of retaining sufficient information content during the translation while maintaining cross-modal latent space consistency. In a qualitative evaluation trial, human evaluators were furthermore able to match musical samples with the images which generated them with accuracies of up to 73%.

title: Trading mean-reversion portfolios: a reinforcement learning approach
authors: Alessio Brini and Daniele Tantari
abstract: Portfolio optimization is an active field of research in the financial domain that in the recent years started to be influenced by the machine learning paradigm. In particular, reinforcement learning (RL) represents the proper framework for optimizing sequential financial decisions over the course of time. To demonstrate it, we generated a series of synthetic experiments to assess the ability of value-based RL to retrieve the underlying known dynamics of simulated financial returns. Results are compared to those obtained by a dynamic programming closed-form optimal solution, which allows us to effectively evaluate the performance obtained by both tabular and deep RL.

title: Training a Cooperative Team in Google Football Environment Using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Witalis Domitrz, Zuzanna Opała, Mateusz Sieniawski, Konrad Staniszewski
abstract: Our team worked on creating top-performing football agents in the Google Research Football environment. We focused on the more challenging multi-agent scenarios, where our agents control four football players (all except goalkeeper). Our best agents were trained using self-play. Throughout the project we used two approaches to the training - centralised, where one network controls all the agents, and decentralised, where each agent evaluates its actions independently. We have found a surprising difference in the performance of these architectures: counter-intuitively, the decentralised one performed better in a full game, which highlights a need for a comprehensive comparison of the architectures.

title: Molecule Attention Transformer
authors: Łukasz Maziarka (1,2), Tomasz Danel (1,2),  Sławomir Mucha (2), Krzysztof Rataj (1), Jacek Tabor (2), Stanisław Jastrzębski (3,4)
abstract: Properties of a molecule depend on a variety of relationships between its atoms. On a high level, these relationships might include spatial proximity, the existence of a chemical bond, or simply a co-occurrence of two atoms. However, the commonly used graph-based models use only the chemical bonds to define the neighbourhood. Motivated by this we propose Molecule Attention Transformer (MAT) model. Our key innovation is augmenting the attention mechanism in Transformer using the inter-atomic distances, and the molecular graph structure. Experiments on molecular property prediction tasks show that our method outperforms all the other tested models on multiple tasks.

title: 3D Mesh Reconstruction from Cardiac ultrasound
authors: Robert-Andrei Moga
abstract: This work proposes a deep learning architecture for reconstructing 3D meshes using triangular polygons from cardiac ultrasound.  My network represents 3D mesh models using a graph convolutional network that encodes the mesh topology. I adopt a coarse to fine approach by deforming iteratively. The convolution operation is repurposed to perform a regression task producing new locations for each vertex with respect to the ground truth. The loss function used is composed by a distance function, an edge normalization term for penalizing long edges and a Laplacian regularization factor for keeping relative position between neighbouring vertices.

title: ARMS: Automated rules management system for fraud detection
authors: David Aparício,   Ricardo Barata,  João Bravo,  João Tiago Ascensão,  Pedro Bizarro
abstract:
Financial institutions, merchants, customers, and government agencies alike suffer fraud-related losses daily, including credit card theft and other scams
An over-conservative decision-maker might block all suspicious activity. However, this also prevents legitimate economic activity. 
Modern automated fraud detection systems consist of a machine learning model and a rule-based system.  An ideal system has only a minimum set of rules that ensure performance while preserving requirements and alerts low.

title: Learning to use tools by watching videos
authors: Kateryna Zorina
abstract: In this work, we use reinforcement learning to find a policy for the tool manipulation task. The task is challenging as the reward is sparse. We study how instructional videos can provide an additional information for learning. The proposed pipeline focuses on finding a policy for the tool and then transfers policy to a robot. Focusing on the tool allows us to transfer the task execution to different robot morphologies.

title: Towards Autonomous Robot Navigation and Exploration with Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Nicolò Botteghi*, Khaled Mustafa*, Beril Sirmaçek**, Mannes Poel***, Stefano Stramigioli*
abstract: We present a map-less path planning algorithm based on Deep Reinforcement Learning for mobile robots navigating in unknown environment that only relies on 40-dimensional raw laser data and odometry information. The planner is trained using a reward function shaped based on the online knowledge of the map of the training environment, obtained using grid-based Rao-Blackwellized particle filter, in an attempt to enhance the obstacle awareness of the agent. The agent is trained in a complex simulated environment and evaluated in two unseen ones. Furthermore, the policy trained in the simulation environment can be directly and successfully transferred to the real robot.

title: No Representation without Transformation
authors: Giorgio Giannone, Saeed Saremi, Jonathan Masci, Christian Osendorfer
abstract: We extend the framework of variational autoencoders to represent transformations explicitly in the latent space. In the family of hierarchical graphical models that emerges, the latent space is populated by higher order objects that are inferred jointly with the latent representations they act on. To explicitly demonstrate the effect of these higher order objects, we show that the inferred latent transformations reflect interpretable properties in the observation space. Furthermore, the model is structured in such a way that in the absence of transformations, we can run inference and obtain generative capabilities comparable with standard variational autoencoders. Finally, utilizing the trained encoder, we outperform the baselines by a wide margin on a challenging out-of-distribution classification task.

title: Explaining of CNN for histopathological image classification
authors: Weronika Hryniewska
abstract: Explainable AI  refers to methods and techniques in the application of AI such that the decision-making process of the solution can be understood by a human. In medical imaging domain it it crucial to understand which image features and patterns take part in decision process, understand reasons of model uncertainty, wrong classifications and eliminate possibility of bias. During this presentation I would like to explain briefly such methods as: Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanations (LIME) and visualizations of intermediate activations and show their results on histopathological images.

title: Legal frames for contact tracing in order to contain pandemics
authors: Marcelina Lech
abstract: My poster refers to legal aspects of contact tracing apps in order to contain pandemics.

title: Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring using Deep Learning
authors: Dea Pujić, Marko Jelić
abstract: Non-Intrusive load monitoring (NILM) in the residential energy applications represents a technique of load disaggregation whereby the individual activation (i.e. on/off status) or individual consumptions (i.e. power draw levels) of appliances are calculated without sensors and only based on total energy meter readings. The presented methodology utilizes deep learning, more specifically CNNs, for this classification/regression problem and is applied in real-time on total consumption measurements from several apartments in Leers, France in order to facilitate energy savings by providing users with feedback regarding how much energy and at what time is being consumed in their home.

title: Object Detection using Deep Learning under lossy image compression
authors: Tomasz Gandor
abstract:
Lossy image compression is very important, and although available storage has risen by a few orders of magnitude since the introduction of JPEG in 1991, so
has the number of images stored every day. Perceived visual quality has been used for determining an optimal compression level, but whether Deep Learning models perceive quality the same way is still an open question. With an extensive computational study using COCO val2017 data set we show how Object Detection models are affected by lossy image compression.

title: Towards generation of stable molecules
authors: Agnieszka Pocha, Sabina Podlewska
abstract:
