The goal of our project is to generate stable molecules. Improving metabolic stability of drugs is important because compounds that undergo fast transformations do not have enough time to induce a desirable therapeutic effect.

We trained graph neural networks to predict metabolic stability of compounds and combined them in an ensemble to improve their performance.

To generate stable molecules we used StackRNN pretrained to generate valid SMILES and a simple RL strategy. Rewards were given by the predictive ensemble. The initial experiments are discouraging but we plan to continue our work in the future.

title: Sign Language Recognition from 3D Video
authors: Mateusz Doliński, Sonia Przygocka
abstract: We study the problem of sign language recognition from 3D videos. Each video consists of 3D point cloud (PCD) frames. We propose new neural network architecture consisting of 2 main parts. The first part embeds each frame into a lower dimensional 1D feature vector. The resulting sequence of embeddings is then passed through a Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) with attention mechanism and fully connected layers in order to classify a video sequence. Our model achieves 98.2% accuracy in the classification task using the Polish Sign Language ToF 84 dataset.

title: Counterfactual explanations of ML models
authors: André Artelt
abstract:
Despite the recent success of Machine Learning, I think that the lack of transparency & explainability is still one of the major issues of modern AI.

Counterfactual explanations are considered to be an intuitive and human-friendly explanation because they tell the user what to do in order to achieve a desired goal.
Unfortunately, most existing algorithms are not that efficient.
Therefore, I developed a convex modelling framework that allows to derive model specific algorithms for computing (plausible) counterfactual explanations very efficiently as well as some other benefits. Furthermore, I implemented my algorithms and already known algorithms in a Python toolbox.

title: Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring using Deep Learning
authors: Dea Pujić and Marko Jelić
abstract: Non-Intrusive load monitoring (NILM) in the residential energy applications represents a technique of load disaggregation whereby the individual activation (i.e. on/off status) or individual consumptions (i.e. power draw levels) of appliances are calculated without sensors and only based on total energy meter readings. The presented methodology utilizes deep learning, more specifically CNNs, for this classification/regression problem and is applied in real-time on total consumption measurements from several apartments in Leers, France in order to facilitate energy savings by providing users with feedback regarding how much energy and at what time is being consumed in their home.

title: Introspective Ensembles for monocular depth estimation
authors: Maciej Bartczak, Mateusz Doliński, David Novotny
abstract: We propose a novel method for monocular depth estimation. While the majority of prior work focused on designing better deep backbones or introducing more powerful regularizers, our contribution seeks to combine different predictors into a single uber-estimator that exploits the strong-points of each prediction. To this end, we propose to use introspective ensembles - a method that exploits recent advances in predicting aleatoric uncertainty to combine predictions according to their estimated degree of confidence. Our quantitative evaluation reveals a strong correlation between attained errors and the uncertainty predictions which warrants a further exploration of the proposed ensembling scheme.

title: Pattern Coloring Task with Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Denis Ergashbaev
abstract: Game emulators have been extensively used as a test bed for reinforcement learning. These algorithms have achieved above-human performance on many environments that require ''reactive'' response from the player. However, until recently there has been limited success at employing reinforcement learning at solving combinatorial tasks. In this work we build a simulated environment where an agent's goal is to color a certain pattern in the most efficient way. We model this problem as a combinatorial reinforcement learning task, develop an effective reward function, and employ a fine-tuned A2C algorithm to solve it.

title: Investigating performance of neural networks approximating microscopic traffic simulations in traffic optimization tasks
authors: Paweł Gora, Maciej Brzeski
abstract: We analyze the accuracy of traffic simulations metamodels based on neural networks, applied to traffic optimization as fitness functions of genetic algorithms. Our metamodels approximate outcomes of traffic simulations (the total time of waiting on a red signal), taking as an input different traffic signal settings, in order to efficiently find (sub)optimal settings. Their accuracy was proven to be very good on randomly selected test sets, but it turned out that the accuracy may drop in case of settings expected (according to genetic algorithms) to be close to local optima, which makes the traffic optimization process more difficult.

title: Clustering Context-Sensitive Embeddings for Semantic Change Detection
authors: Lidia Pivovarova, Matej Martinc, Syrielle Montariol, Elaine Zosa
abstract: This work summarises two recent work on utilizing contextualized embeddings for semantic change detection. In both cases our dataset consists of target words and a corpus containing texts from at least two time periods. The task is to compute a measure of semantic shift for each target word in unsupervised way, relying on the corpus data. We use BERT model to collect embeddings for a target word. These embeddings are then clustered and divergence between cluster distributions is then used as a proxy to semantic change. The method beats state-of-the-art on some public datasets and shows comparable results on other.

title: Gradient boosting model for predicting mutation-resistant peptide candidates for COVID-19 vaccines
authors: Piotr Grzegorczyk, Grzegorz Preibisch, Michael D'Amour, Sharan Ramjee, Michał Borkowski, Aishwarya Chander
abstract: Recent studies suggest that differences in HLA caused by differences in race, ethnicity and geographic location may influence COVID-19 virulence and resistance to vaccines. Because of this, we decided to train gradient boosted decision trees model on all available SARS-CoV-2 genomes to predict how different peptides in vaccine may influence the efficacy of it.

title: ActiveHARNet: Towards On-Device Deep Bayesian Active Learning for Human Activity Recognition
authors: Gautham Krishna Gudur, Prahalathan Sundaramoorthy, Venkatesh Umaashankar
abstract: Two challenges that need to be addressed in on-device deep learning for Human Activity Recognition (HAR) are: first, the model should support on-device incremental training from incoming data to learn user behavior over time; second, suitable ground truthing techniques (like Active Learning) should help establish labels on-the-fly. We propose ActiveHARNet, a resource-efficient deep model which supports on-device Incremental Active Learning, through approximations in Bayesian Neural Networks using dropout. This is combined with suitable acquisition functions for active learning. Empirical results on two datasets show considerable efficiency boost with substantially low number of acquired points (~60% reduction) during incremental learning.
keywords: Bayesian Active Learning, On-Device Human Activity Recognition and Fall Detection, Incremental Learning

title: Disguising Text as an Image using Generative Adversarial Network
authors: Anditya Arifianto, Made Raharja Surya Mahadi, Adriansyah Dwi Rendragraha, Malik Anhar Maulana, Triwidyastuti Jamaluddin, Muhammad Ferianda Satya, Rajabandanu Subhi
abstract: Image is often used as a cover to hide sensitive data inside it. This approach is considered a good addition in securing information to cryptography. In this study, we developed an encryption mechanism to not only conceal messages, but transforming them into images. We use Generative Adversarial Network to develop the encryption and decryption models. Text data is converted into a word vector using word2vec model which then used as input for the encryption model to produce the word images. Based on our experiments, we were able to produce images with 98% accuracy of reversible words.

title: Neural Index for Imperfect Terms Matching in the Wikification Process
authors: Szymon Olewniczak
abstract: Our project aims to create an efficient method for imperfect terms matching in texts, that can be applied for the Wikification. Wikification is a process of creating hyperlinks for a given text corpus, referencing it to relevant Wikipedia articles. Currently, we are working on a neural network for an efficient Levenstein distance embedding for Wikipedia's articles titles. The poster summarises some of the results that we obtained.

title: Foreground-Background Ambient Sound Scene Separation
authors: Michel Olvera, Emmanuel Vincent, Romain Serizel and Gilles Gasso
abstract: Ambient sound scenes typically comprise multiple short events occurring on top of a somewhat stationary background. We consider the task of separating these events from the background, which we call foreground-background ambient sound scene separation. We propose a deep learning based separation framework with a suitable feature normalization scheme and an optional auxiliary network capturing the background statistics, and we investigate its ability to handle the great variety of sound classes encountered in ambient sound scenes, which have often not been seen in training. Our experimental findings demonstrate the generalization ability of the proposed approach.

title: Optimal operation of electric batteries using reinforcement learning
authors: Mykhailo Manukian
abstract: The goal of this project is to use machine learning to develop a controller that will determine optimal operation of available batteries, i.e. when and how the batteries should be charged/discharged. To develop such a controller, the load profile of an exemplary country is available with hourly resolution. The objective of using batteries is to effectively reduce the variability of load, i.e. daily difference between maximum and minimum power taken from the power grid. This objective is justified by the fact that supplying the peak portion of load is typically much more expensive than supplying energy during minimum load conditions.

title: End-to-end Training for Robust Face Recognition
authors: Aleksandr Safin
abstract: We propose a joint approach for face verification on raw non-preprocessed images.This joint network performs denoising-demosaicing and face verification meaningthat it outputs both the RGB image and embedding of face image. In this work wehave shown that joint fine-tuning is a bit more effective in terms of accuracy forface verification, though visually the image quality does not change significantly

title: Attention-Based Curiosity-Driven Exploration in Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Patrik Reizinger; Márton Szemenyei
abstract: Reinforcement Learning enables to train an agent via interaction with the environment. Our aim is to develop means for the better incorporation of state- and/or action-dependent information into existing intrinsic reward formulations with the attention mechanism. A curiosity-based approach - the Intrinsic Curiosity Module - is extended. The proposed model utilizes attention to emphasize features for the dynamic models within the Intrinsic Curiosity Module; moreover, we also modify the loss function, resulting in a new curiosity formulation, which we call rational curiosity (RCM). The corresponding implementation can be found at https://github.com/rpatrik96/AttA2C/.

title: Automated Detection of Above Anvil Cirrus Plumes (AACPs)
authors: Roshni Biswas, Charles Liles, Kristopher Bedka
abstract: The above anvil cirrus plume (AACP) is a weather phenomenon that signifies an intense tropopause-penetrating updraft injecting cirrus clouds several kilometers into the stratosphere. Though AACPs can be identified by the human eye, no automated AACP detection methods currently exist. Lack of detection inhibits understanding of where and how often AACPs occur, and influence on stratospheric air composition. This study demonstrates automated emergent AACP identification based on a U-Net model using only satellite infrared and visible reflected sunlight imagery. Model performance is quantitatively benchmarked with human AACP identifications and qualitatively assessed through animated detections from GOES-16 1-minute temporal resolution imagery.

title: Histopathological Image Classification for Cancer Detection using Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Mikolaj Jaworski
abstract: Different models are being developed simultaneously for images coming from histopathological examinations, mammographics, blood smears, X-rays, ultrasounds, MRIs. Many models are preforming better or close to dostor's classification accuracy and are much more time efficient. Development of such a solution was the goal of the work. Classification of histopathologic images was performed in order to detect presence of metastatic cells. Data included over 275 thousands of images. CNNs with transfer learning and regularization methods were applied. The best performing architecture was DenseNet 201, which had result of 97.56% AUC on first half and 97.08\% on the second.

title: Towards Adversarial Robustness of Synthetic Code Generation Datasets
authors: Mrinal Anand, Pratik Kayal, Mayank Singh
abstract:
Automatic code synthesis from natural language descriptions is a challenging task. In the recent past, we witness massive progress on the development of code generation systems for domain-specific languages (DSLs) employing sequence-to-sequence deep learning techniques. In this paper, we specifically experiment with AlgoLisp DSL-based generative models and showcase their extreme dataset bias through the different classes of adversarial examples. We also present a simple transformer based encoder-decoder model that outperforms the majority of AlgoLisp DSL-based baselines. However, consistent with the previous baselines, the proposed model achieves poor performance under adversarial.
settings.

title: DCT-Domain Deep Convolutional Neural Network for Multiple JPEG Compression Classification
authors: Vinay Verma, Nikita Agarwal and Nitin Khanna
abstract:
Ease of digital image capture and sharing is accompanied by widespread usage of user-friendly image editing software. 
We are in an era where digital images can be very easily used for the massive spread of false information and their integrity needs to be seriously questioned. 
The application of multiple lossy compressions on images is an essential part of any image editing pipeline involving lossy compressed images. 
This paper aims to address the problem of classifying images based on the number of JPEG compressions they have undergone, by utilizing deep convolutional neural networks in the DCT domain.

title: Zero-Shot Source Code Author Identification: ​A Lexicon and Layout Independent Approach​
authors: Pegah Hozhabrierdi, Dunai Fuentes Hitos, Chilukuri K. Mohan​
abstract: We tackle the challenge of Zero-Shot identification of authors of source code, which can be used with no prior samples of authors outside of the training data. In our approach, a feedforward neural network is first trained on a multi-class classification task. Then, a substantial part of this network is duplicated and reused to compare code samples (FDR architecture). We propose new input features for this model, called Variable-Independent Nested Bigrams, that provide robustness against frequently-used obfuscation methods. FDR performs accurately even on code samples from unknown authors, on data obtained from Google Code Jam, an international coding competition platform.

title: Quantifying Gender Bias in Hyperbolic Word Embeddings
authors: Vaibhav Kumar, Vaibhav Kumar and Tenzin Singhay Bhotia

title: Online Neural Network based model identification procedure of a fixed-wing UAV
authors: Marko Maljkovic
abstract: In this project, we aim to design an online, window based, neural network procedure that learns the longitudinal dynamics model of a small fixed-wing UAV while the vehicle is flying. A custom loss function is proposed to account for the noise induced by the labeling procedure. 5 Training trajectories were acquired through HIL simulations and were used for the 5-fold cross validation procedure. A grid search over a subset of learning rates, model configurations, number of hidden nodes and window sizes was conducted to obtain the best models for different criteria. For those models, we also estimate the convergence times.

title: Principal Neighbourhood Aggregation for Graph Nets
authors: Gabriele Corso*, Luca Cavalleri*, Dominique Beaini, Pietro Liò, Petar Veličković
abstract: Graph Neural Networks have been shown to be effective models for different predictive tasks on graph-structured data. We extend the current theoretical framework for their expressive power to include continuous features, which occur regularly in real-world input domains and within the hidden layers of GNNs, and we demonstrate the requirement for multiple aggregation functions. Accordingly, we propose Principal Neighbourhood Aggregation (PNA), a novel architecture combining multiple aggregators with degree-scalers. Finally, we compare the capacity of different models via a novel multi-task benchmark from graph theory and existing benchmarks from real-world domains, all of which demonstrate the strength of our model.

title: Convolutional Neural Networks with Intermediate Loss for 3D Super-Resolution of CT and MRI Scans
authors: Mariana-Iuliana Georgescu , Radu Tudor Ionescu, Nicolae Verga
abstract: We propose an approach for the single-image super-resolution of 3D CT/MRI scans. Our method is based on deep convolutional neural networks composed of 10 convolutional layers and an intermediate upscaling layer that is placed after the first 6 convolutional layers. Our first CNN, which increases the resolution on two axes (width and height), is followed by a second CNN, which increases the resolution on the third axis (depth). Different from other methods, we compute the loss with respect to the ground-truth high-resolution output right after the upscaling layer, in addition to computing the loss after the last convolutional layer.

title: Deep Learning for Dental Hyperspectral Image Analysis
authors: Oleksandr Boiko
abstract:
The aim of this work is automatic and efficient detection of medically-relevant features from oral and dental hyperspectral images by applying up-to-date deep learning convolutional neural network techniques. This will help dentists to identify and classify unhealthy areas automatically and to prevent the progression of diseases. 

📌 Hyperspectral imaging approach allows one to do so without exposing the patient to ionizing X-ray radiation. Spectral imaging provides information in the visible and near-infrared wavelength ranges. 
📌 The dataset used in this paper contains 116 hyperspectral images from 18 patients taken from different viewing angles. Image annotation (ground truth) includes 38 classes in six different sub-groups assessed by dental experts. 
📌 Mask region-based convolutional neural network (Mask R-CNN) is used as a deep learning model, for instance segmentation of areas. 
📌 Preliminary results show high potential and accuracy for classification and segmentation of different classes.

title: Defending against Adversarial Attacks through Variational Autoencoders
authors: Delia Dumitru, Petru Hlihor, Riccardo Volpi, Luigi Malago
abstract: In this experiment we test our adversarial defense based on Variational Autoencoders against the Carlini-Wagner and Expectation Over Transformation attacks, proposed by Carlini et al. (2017) and Athalye et. al. (2017) respectively. We show comparative results using a Variational Autoencoder and a Contractive Variational Autoencoder on the MNIST and FashionMNIST data sets. Additionally we present a brief analysis of the latent space of the autoencoders.

title: Why do CNN design better buildings?
authors: Aleksandra Jastrzębska, Stanisław Jastrzębski
abstract: Designing structures such as bridges can be formulated as an optimization problem. Recent work has shown that using a deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) enables finding better solutions to this optimization problem. Specifically, they use a randomly initialized DCNN to transform a lower resolution structure to the full structure, and optimize with respect to the low-resolution structure.  We took a closer look at the effect of this reparametrization and found that using DCNN impacts strongly the initial phase of training by biasing the optimization towards simpler and better solutions.

title: BacterOMIC: Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing Enhanced By Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Michał Bortkiewicz, Krystian Kurek and Paweł Dębski, PhD
abstract: In this work, we show how analytical methods based on machine learning can support novel solutions in the area of medical diagnostics and in particular the determination of antimicrobial susceptibility to antibiotics. BacterOMIC uses ML methods to observe the incubation chambers, improve the quality of collected data and its classification. Here, we present unsupervised anomaly detection method and briefly report most important results. We focus on the recognition and classification of optical disturbances that are created as a result of microbial metabolism and may alter the results of susceptibility test.

title: Causal Macrovariable Detection through Neural Networks
authors: Benedikt Höltgen
abstract: We introduce a new approach to detect causally salient macrovariables in high-dimensional datasets. Motivated by information theoretic considerations, we adapt Variational Autoencoders such that they yield these macrovariables in the form of neuron activations. We show that this approach allows to recover ground-truth macrovariables from simulated data. In experiments on natural data, we are able to detect different versions of the El Nino phenomenon that are discussed in the climate science literature. Further analyses on the simulated data indicate the possibility to determine the causal direction through additive noise models.

title: Improving Crops Disease Classification with Deep Unsupervised Deblurring Approach
authors: 1. Javed Ahmad  2. Fahad Shamshad  3. Junaid Maqbool
abstract: Crop diseases pose a major threat to world food security, and their timely identification is of utmost importance. However, the prevalence of distortion and motion blur in the crop images during image acquisition make image enhancement a mandatory step. Recently, deep learning-based approaches have shown the state of the art results for image enhancement. However, one critical limitation of these deep learning-based approaches is the requirement of high-quality noiseless ground truth images that are difficult to obtain in many agricultural applications. To solve this issue, we leverage a recently proposed deep learning-based approach that does not require ground-truth images to remove the motion blur. We show the effectiveness of our proposed approach on wheat and rice plant disease datasets.

title: Deep learning of liquid crystal operation
authors: Dominik Vašinka, Martin Bielak and Miroslav Ježek
abstract: Polarization states of light play a vital role in many applications in optical communications, photonic information processing, optical metrology, as well as many others, and therefore a fast and precise method of their preparation and detection is required. Nematic liquid crystals present an essential method, although with a downside of limited precision. In our work, we aim to eliminate this obstacle and the presented deep neural network model enhanced fidelity up to 99.996 %. Moreover, we demonstrate the benefits of deep neural networks in comparison with the analytical description and dataset interpolation.

title: State Planning Policy Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jacek Płocharczyk, Mikhail Zanka, Jacek Cyranka
abstract: We introduce a novel formulation of reinforcement learning, where the aim of the actor is to propose the next desired state instead of an action. In order to communicate the actor output to the environment, we incorporate a learnable inverse dynamics control model. We implemented state planning policy reinforcement learning using state-of-the-art reinforcement learning algorithms including DDPG and SAC. In spite of the search for the optimal policy being performed in the state-space, which has a significantly larger dimension than the action-space, we report quite surprising results that are competitive to state-of-the-art RL approaches in the classical setting.

title: Deep Learning for classification and segmentationfor understanding clouds from satellite images
authors: Kirill Vishnyakov, Mukharbek Organokov
abstract: This analysis performs cloud classification and segmentation using satellite images. Murky boundaries between different forms of clouds lead to obstacles in traditional rule-based algorithms cloud features separation. In this analysis, deep learning algorithms are build to identify regions in satellite images that contain certain cloud formations. The dataset used in the analysis released on the Kaggle platform.  It contains four labels: Fish, Flower, Gravel, and Sugar. The cloud segmentation and classification is done using deep learning models. These models led to a Top 6% solution in Kaggle competition. Various improvements of the algorithm are described and results are presented.

title: Deep Learning for classification and segmentation for understanding clouds from satellite images
authors: Kirill Vishnyakov, Mukharbek Organokov
abstract: This analysis performs cloud classification and segmentation using satellite images. Murky boundaries between different forms of clouds lead to obstacles in traditional rule-based algorithms cloud features separation. In this analysis, deep learning algorithms are build to identify regions in satellite images that contain certain cloud formations. The dataset used in the analysis released on the Kaggle platform.  It contains four labels: Fish, Flower, Gravel, and Sugar. The cloud segmentation and classification is done using deep learning models. These models led to a Top 6% solution in Kaggle competition. Various improvements of the algorithm are described and results are presented.

title: Deep Learning of Quantum Entanglement
authors: Dominik Koutný and Miroslav Ježek
abstract: We approach the problem of inferring quantum correlations and quantum entanglement from incomplete, or even randomized, measurements. We show that even with the lack of seemingly necessary information, deep neural networks will provide an accurate description of an amount of entanglement present in the quantum system. Our results show a lower error when compared with state-of-the-art methods of quantum tomography. Minimizing measurement resources together with maintaining the superior performance of information extraction is crucial for detection correlations in condensed matter systems, characterization of photonic entanglement sources with applications in secure communications, and execution of protocols in quantum information processing.

title: Memory modelling with the usage of recurrent neural networks  in actor-critic algorithms.
authors: Daniel Klepacki
abstract:
I chose three promising state value function algorithms PPO, A2C, IMPALA and implemented software that allows them to be used in conjunction with recurrent networks. After gathering the results of experiments, I did a comparative analysis and an evaluation of the algorithms used. The reinforcement learning problems used in this work to test the quality of the proposed methods were well-known environments imitating Atari 2600 games.
As a result of the work undertaken, I was able to draw some important conclusions regarding the quality, stability and versatility of the proposed solutions and the impact of memory use on their capabilities.

title: Reinforcement learning based brain-computer interface
authors: Maciej Śliwowski, Piotr Tempczyk, Marian Dovgialo, Jarosław Żygierewicz
abstract:
Brain-computer interfaces enable interactions between human and machine without using muscles. We focus on EEG based interface which uses event-related potentials and error-related potentials (ErrP) to infer user intentions and to optimize BCI actions.
We propose a reinforcement learning (RL) based approach using Deep Q-network (DQN) algorithm to control the actions and BCI decisions. An agent is trained to select an action which is either presentation of a specific stimulus or making an intention prediction. ErrPs were used to compute the feedback reward. We demonstrated that RL approaches can achieve the same or better performance than ones using straightforward
policy.

title: Gated Deep Memory Updater
authors: Lidia Wojciechowska, Paweł Wawrzyński
abstract: We address the problem of memory modification in recurrent neural networks. Existing solutions do not allow the usage of whichever function for this transformation. Therefore, a recurrent layer type has been proposed, using for this purpose a multilayer perceptron, which is a universal approximator. The concept of a state regularization was also presented, which allows avoiding vanishing and exploding gradient. The results indicate the great potential of the proposed solutions in the case of difficult tasks that require complex memory processing.

title: Emerging Representations for Counting in a Neural Network Agent Interactingwith a Multimodal Environment
authors: Silvester Sabathiel, James L. McClelland, Trygve Solstad
abstract:
Here we investigate how a neural network agent develops representations for key concepts
of counting while learning to perform several different
counting tasks in a multimodal, interactive environment. We
identify neural activity and connection patterns that realize a)
a representation of the entity to count that was invariant to
the task. b) an entity-to-number-word mapping, and c) a representation
of the number of entities that have been counted,
that was shared between tasks. The results support the notion
that abstract representations of number can arise from integrating
experiences across a range of number-related tasks.

title: Temperature-driven Regression Models for Predicting Insect Development
authors: Sarvar Abdullaev
abstract: Poster reviews common temperature-driven regression models for predicting insect development. It adopts the law of effective temperature for insect development as a scientific basis and demonstrates a linear regression model the parameters of which reflect the thermal constant of each species. Although linear models take into account the lower temperature-bound for insect development, they cannot accommodate the upper temperature-bound in which insect stops developing or even dies off. Therefore, non-linear models which can also estimate the peak temperature after which the insect development rate slows down are presented too. Parameters of these models are estimated using LSE, ML, LMA etc.

title: Quantifying Gender Bias in Hyperbolic Word Embeddings
authors: Vaibhav Kumar, Vaibhav Kumar and Tenzin Singhay Bhotia
abstract: Distributed Word embedding models are now the standard way for word representation in Natural Language Processing (NLP). However, it has been found that Euclidean word embedding models such as GloVe and Word2Vec are susceptible to human-like prejudices that arise from the training corpus. In this paper, we extend the study of biases to the recently popularized Non-Euclidean word embeddings. We propose gyrocosine bias, a novel metric for quantifying bias in hyperbolic word embeddings. We observe that gender-bias heavily manifests itself in hyperbolic word embeddings, showing similar characteristics as its Euclidean counterpart.

title: A Generic and Model-Agnostic Exemplar Synthetization Framework for Explainable AI
authors: Antonio Barbalau, Adrian Cosma, Radu Tudor Ionescu, Marius Popescu
abstract: We have proposed a novel black-box exemplar synthetization framework which employs a generative model, acting as a prior for generating data, and traverses its latent space using a novel evolutionary strategy with momentum updates. Our framework is generic because it can employ any underlying generator and it can be applied to any input data. Additionally, since we use a zero-order optimization method, our framework is model-agnostic, in the sense that the machine learning model that we aim to explain is a black-box requiring no access or knowledge of the internal structure or the training data of the model.

title: Context-Aware Learning to Rank with Self-Attention
authors: Przemysław Pobrotyn, Tomasz Bartczak, Mikołaj Synowiec, Radosław Białobrzeski, Jarosław Bojar
abstract: In our work we adapt the Transformer architecture for task of learning to rank. As a result we get a model which scores documents in a list including context (aka other documents present in the list). We compare our method with common LTR approaches across different loss functions. The experiments show that proposed algorithm performs better than previously known methods. We also introduce a PyTorch framework which allows to reproduce our experiments and is a good starting point for research in neural LTR models.

title: Iterative cone-beam CT reconstruction enhanced by deep learning
authors: Martin Buchacek
abstract: Iterative algorithms are one of the state-of-the-art methods for CT image reconstruction. We extend the reconstruction algorithm for cone-beam CT images by using the UNet architecture with 3D kernels. First, we find that using unfinished iterations as the input and finished iterations as target, the trained network can replace several consecutive iteration steps. Second, we show that the network can be used to remove sampling artifacts from reconstructions generated from subsampled projections. This way, using only 30% of the radiation dose would yield comparable image quality to the full-dose reconstructions.

title: Margonem Outfit Generation with GANs
authors: Daniel Klepacki, Wiktor Michalski, Wojciech Maciejewski, Maciej Szulik
abstract: The aim of our project is to generate new graphics for characters in a game called Margonem. The original characters are drawn using a technique called pixel art and their size is 32x48 pixels. Our approach is to use existing methods for generating images and to test them on this task. So far we have tested 2 models: DCGAN and WGAN. Results from those models were not satisfactory yet and we are still developing new ideas on how to improve them. In the future we are planning on testing other models such as VAE and StyleGAN.

title: Anomaly Detection in Raw Audio Heartbeat Sounds  using Variational AutoEncoders
authors: Robert Colt, Csongor Huba Varady, Riccardo Volpi, Luigi Malago
abstract:
In this paper I will present our work regarding the development of a semi-supervised anomaly detection method for raw audio heartbeat sounds. Our method uses features learned by a Wavenet autoencoder, trained with a modified objective, employing the Maximum Mean Discrepancy. We perform 
clustering on the latent representations and reconstrucction metrics of the heartbeat data, and use the learned clusters to predict the anomalies of new encoded signals.
We evaluate our method on a problem proposed by the PASCAL Classifying Heart Sounds Challenge and report close and comparable results to other supervised learning techniques exploiting ad hoc feature extraction.

title: Human Motion Generation by Stochastic Conditioning of Recurrent Networks
authors: Himanshu Buckchash, Balasubramanian Raman
abstract: Human motion generation is a stochastic process. The 3D motion generation task requires efficient regulation of stochasticity and a controlled approach for error-accumulation. Current generation approaches either fail to check error-amplitude or to preserve the signal. In this work, we discuss an approach to regulate the stochasticity for 3D human motion generation. This is achieved by designing a fully differentiable, block-based autoregressive RNN architecture by incorporating variable auto-conditioning length along with variational inference. The proposed approach provides a lesser joint prediction error with stable motion generation.

title: BERT for Sequence-to-Sequence Multi-label Text Classification
authors: Ramil Yarullin, Pavel Serdyukov
abstract: We study the BERT language representation model and the sequence generation model with BERT encoder for multi-label text classification task. We show that sequence generating BERT model achieves decent results in a significantly fewer number of training epochs compared to standard BERT. We also introduce and examine experimentally a mixed model, which is an ensemble of original BERT and sequence generating BERT models. Our experiments demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms current baselines in several metrics on three well-studied multi-label classification datasets with English texts and two private Yandex Taxi datasets with Russian texts.

title: Comparative Analysis of Music Emotion Recognition using Deep Neural Networks
authors: Gloria-Ruxandra Maciuca
abstract:
In this small research, the task of recognizing emotion in music was tackled from different perspectives and using various deep learning models.
The emotions were represented according to Russell's model of affect, that maps them in valence-arousal space.
Using MFCCs features, the task was approached as regression and also as classification, illustrated on both Feed-Forward and Convolutional neural networks. 
Each method was further extended considering the output type. The problems are solved by model that outputs a point/quadrant in emotion-space and a group of two models each separately predicting or classifying valence and arousal or energy and intensity, respectively.

title: Buffer Allocation in Flowlines using Q-Learning
authors: Lisa C. Günther
abstract:
A problem, known as buffer allocation problem, is encountered in the manufacturing facilities of different industries: How much buffer space should be allocated between the stations of a production line, so that the production runs as smoothly as possible – while keeping costs low at the same time? 
As current approaches suffer from multiple drawbacks, it is tested whether deep reinforcement learning can be used to find a feasible and sensible buffer space distribution for production lines with random stops. The problem is formulated accordingly and a preliminary computational experiment is conducted using Q-learning, that shows promising first results.

title: The use of machine learning techniques to assess mammalian pre-implantation embryo quality
authors: Camilla Mapstone, Dr Berenika Plusa, Dr Julia Handl
abstract: IVF treatment is growing in popularity, partially due to rises in infertility, however success rates remain low. The selection of an embryo suitable for transfer is currently carried out by visual assessment of time-lapse videos. This is subjective and can lead to different results between embryologists. Techniques from pattern recognition and machine learning may provide suitable tools to help support this task, leading to more reliable predictions. Here we use supervised learning methods to examine bright-field images of human embryos. We also explore use of the LIME software in explaining our predictions to increase the trustworthiness of our models .

title: An efficient manifold density estimator for all recommendation systems
authors: Jacek Dąbrowski, Barbara Rychalska, Michał Daniluk, Dominika Basaj, Konrad Gołuchowski, Piotr Babel, Andrzej Michałowski
abstract: Many unsupervised representation learning methods belong to the class of similarity learning models. While various modality-specific approaches exist for different types of data, a core property of many methods is that representations of similar inputs are close under some similarity function. We propose EMDE (Efficient Manifold Density Estimator) – a framework utilizing arbitrary vector representations with the property of local similarity to succinctly represent smooth probability densities on Riemannian manifolds. Applying EMDE to both top-k and session-based recommendation settings, we establish new state-of-the-art results on multiple open datasets in both uni-modal and multi-modal settings.

title: Quantifying Gender Bias in Hyperbolic Word Embeddings
authors: Vaibhav Kumar, Vaibhav Kumar, Tenzin Singhay Bhotia
abstract: Distributed Word embedding models are now the standard way for word representation in Natural Language Processing (NLP). However, it has been found that Euclidean word embedding models such as GloVe and Word2Vec are susceptible to human-like prejudices that arise from the training corpus. In this paper, we extend the study of biases to the recently popularized Non-Euclidean word embeddings. We propose gyrocosine bias, a novel metric for quantifying bias in hyperbolic word embeddings. We observe that gender-bias heavily manifests itself in hyperbolic word embeddings, showing similar characteristics as its Euclidean counterpart.

title: Neurocomputational model of value-based decision-making
authors: Anush Ghambaryan, Vasily Klucharev, Boris Gutkin, Etienne Koechlin
abstract: A recent study (Rouault, Drugowitch, & Koechlin, 2019) proposed a computational model of value-based decision-making and confirmed their hypothesis that an additive (sub-optimal) model fits human choices better than optimal multiplicative models. We replicated this conclusion in a behavioral study. Moreover, we manipulated proposed rewards of the task in low and high parity conditions in order to check the normalization step of the algorithm. We did not find evidence contradicting that. Besides, we conducted the experiment in gain and loss domains to check the reward representation effect. We did not find evidence that choices were different in two domains.

title: Toroidal AutoEncoder
authors: Maciej J. Mikulski and Jaroslaw Duda
abstract:
We propose a new approach to enforce uniform distribution on a d-dimensional torus in a latent space of an autoencoder. We introduce a circular spring loss, which enforces minibatch points to be equally spaced and satisfy cyclic boundary conditions.

As an example of its application we propose multiple-path interpolations. Minimal distance geodesic between two points in uniform distribution on latent space of angles becomes a line, however, torus topology allows us to choose such lines in alternative ways, going through different edges of $[-\pi,\pi]^d$.

Link to the paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.12286

title: Classification of Radio Galaxies using less amount of data
authors: Ashwin Samudre, Lijo George, Yogesh Wadadekar
abstract:
In this paper, we explore the task of radio galaxy classification based on morphology using deep learning methods with a focus on using less amount of data. We apply transfer learning techniques as well as advanced techniques like cyclical learning rate, discriminative learning to train the model rapidly. Our results show that focusing on a small but curated dataset along with the use of best practices to train the neural network can lead to good results. Automated classification techniques will be crucial for upcoming surveys with next generation radio telescopes expected to detect thousands of
new sources in the future.

title: Road damage detection using deep learning
authors: Martyna Kumaszka
abstract: In the process of damage detection of road surfaces many methods are based on image processing techniques. Most of them focus solely on detection of presence or absence of damage. This work proposes deep learning model based on YOLO (You Only Look Once) architecture for the localization of damage in the image. The experimental results show that this method can effectively detect damages on image with 0.75 F1 measure value.

title: Is noisy quadratic model of training of deep neural networks realistic enough?
authors: Michał Zmysłowski, Stanisław Jastrzębski
abstract: The empirical risk function of a neural network is usually highly non-convex. Therefore, it is hard to obtain theoretical results about its optimisation that are meaningful to practitioners without making strong assumptions. Although, it is not clear how such assumption should be made. We suggest to base them on properties of empirical risk observed in practice. Based on a literature study, we distinguish five such properties. We review a noisy quadratic model that assumes two of the highlighted properties. We show that the assumptions are insufficient to model the effect that the batch size has optimisation of neural networks.

title: A Machine Learning Approach for Road  Cycling Race Performance Prediction
authors: Leonid Kholkine, Tom de Schepper, Tim Verdonck, Steven Latré
abstract: Predicting cycling race results has always been a task left to experts with a lot of domain knowledge. This is largely due to the fact that the outcomes of cycling races can be rather erratic and depend on an extensive set of parameters. We believe that due to the availability of historical data and the recent advances in machine learning, the prediction of the outcomes of cycling races becomes feasible. In this work, we present a framework for predicting future race outcomes by using machine learning. We focus on the Tour of Flanders as our proof-of-concept.

title: Improving benchmarks for autonomous vehicles testing using synthetically generated images
authors: Aleksander Lukashou
abstract: Nowadays autonomous technologies are a very heavily explored area and particularly computer vision as the main component of vehicle perception. The quality of the whole vision system based on neural networks relies on the dataset it was trained on. It is extremely difficult to find traffic sign datasets from most of the counties of the world. In this paper, we propose a solution on how to update model using a small dataset from the country vehicle will be used in. We achieved about 10 percent quality raise and expect even better results during future experiments.
